awd_titl_txt: Evolution of Bacterial Pathways for the Degradation of Synthetic Nitroaromatic Compounds
awd_abstract_narration:
Nitroaromatic compounds are problematic environmental contaminants due to their stability and toxicity. Because many nitroaromatic compounds are synthetic and have been recently introduced into the environment, bacteria have had a relatively short time to develop pathways for their degradation. This project investigates the mechanisms by which bacteria adapt to synthetic chemicals and evolve new degradation pathways. Acidovorax sp. strain JS42, which was isolated from a site that was contaminated with nitrobenzene, utilizes 2-nitrotoluene and nitrobenzene as sole carbon, nitrogen and energy sources. In this strain, a single new enzymatic reaction is required to catalyze the conversion of these synthetic nitroarene compounds to easily degraded natural products (catechols). The key reaction is catalyzed by a Rieske-type dioxygenase that oxidizes nitrobenzene and nitrotoluene substrates at the nitro-substituted carbon, which results in the release of nitrite. Acidovorax sp. JS42 has not only developed the ability to grow on these synthetic nitroarenes, but it has also developed a strategy to regulate expression of the dioxygenase genes in response to nitroarene compounds. The current project focuses on identifying the global affects of exposure to nitroarene substrates on the physiology of Acidovorax sp. strain JS42. The goals of the project are to: 1) investigate to what extent the newly evolved nitroarene degradation pathway is integrated into global control mechanisms including catabolite repression and nitrogen control, 2) identify mechanisms of solvent tolerance and general stress responses induced by nitroarene compounds, and 3) identify the complete range of mutations resulting from long- and short-term selection of Acidovorax sp. JS42 for growth on the alternative nitroarene substrates 3-nitrotoluene and 4-nitrotoluene. As part of the study, additional laboratory evolution experiments will be carried out under specific selective conditions in order to generate strains with expanded nitroarene degradation abilities. To achieve these goals, a combination of comparative genomics, transcriptomics, and detailed analyses of the genes, enzymes and regulatory mechanisms will be used. These studies will increase our understanding of how bacteria evolve new biodegradation pathways in response to environmental pressures, and whether control of pathway gene expression is integrated into global carbon and nitrogen control systems.

Broader Impacts

The proposed research will contribute to the education and training of high school, undergraduate, and graduate students, providing them with valuable hands-on laboratory experience. The PI hosts high school students through the UC Davis Young Scholars Program, and also trains summer undergraduate students through the Summer Undergraduate Research Program, which brings students (many from underrepresented groups) from small universities for 10 weeks of summer research. The PI typically has at least two UC Davis undergraduate researchers in the laboratory throughout the year. The PI will also continue to contribute to an undergraduate course called "Introduction to Research", which exposes undergraduates to current ongoing research in the Department of Microbiology. In addition, freely available user-friendly web-based tools for comparative genomics will be developed in conjunction with this project. These analysis tools will be extremely useful to a wide range of research scientists studying genomes from all three domains of life.

Intellectual merit

Over the past 50 years, synthetic chemicals have become increasingly important in our everyday lives, often making daily life easier and better. Unfortunately, many synthetic chemicals can be toxic, and their fate in the environment is not always clear. What has become clear, however, is that bacteria have the ability to rapidly adapt to the presence of synthetic chemicals and take advantage of these potential sources of carbon, nitrogen and energy. We are interested in understanding all aspects of the development of new bacterial pathways for the degradation of synthetic chemicals, including changes in enzyme substrate ranges to allow new catalytic reactions, changes in regulatory systems to allow appropriate control of the genes encoding the new or modified enzymes, as well as the development of sensory and transport systems that allow bacteria to detect and take up these chemicals. This project addressed the evolution of bacterial pathways for the degradation of the synthetic industrial chemicals nitrobenzene and 2-nitrotoluene. In this study we carried out laboratory evolution experiments to evolve bacterial strains that grow on alternative mononitrotoluene isomers. Our findings showed that changes in the activity and specificity of the dioxygenase enzyme that catalyzes the first step in nitrotoluene degradation were critical, but that additional mutations elsewhere in the genome improved the ability of the strains to grow on and degrade nitrotoluenes. In some cases, forcing the bacterial strain to grow on a particular mononitrotoluene isomer reduced the ability to grow on the original isomer. However, by alternating selection on one, then the other isomer, we were able to select for strains that grow on all three mononitrotoluenes. Such strains had multiple changes near the active site of the initial dioxygenase that allowed it to accommodate all three substrates. In this study, we also demonstrated that the presence of alternative carbon sources but not alternative nitrogen sources affected the expression of genes required for degradation of nitrotoluenes. In the presence of simple organic acids such as acetate, propionate and succinate, expression of the genes encoding nitrotoluene dioxygenase was repressed. This is an important finding because the presence of these common organic acids could impact the effectiveness of the bacterium in bioremediation of a nitrotoluene-contaminated site. No such regulatory control was exerted by the presence of the common nitrogen sources ammonium and nitrate. The findings of this project highlight how rapidly bacteria can evolve to take advantage of new carbon and energy sources. The real-time laboratory evolution studies carried out in this project recapitulate natural selections that occur in contaminated environments where man-made pollutants are present. This use of a simplified system consisting of one bacterial strain and one pollutant class allowed us to dissect the process and identify specific mutational events that occurred.

 

Broader Impacts

This study has impacts on the field of bioremediation. Through natural selection we have obtained variants of the original bacterial isolate that grow on all three nitrotoluene isomers. Since contaminated sites are typically contaminated with mixtures of pollutants these bacterial strains may be useful for application clean up of contaminated environments. A postdoctoral fellow, four graduate students, several undergraduates, and a high school student directly benefited from participating in the project by learning the process of carrying out scientific experiments with the appropriate controls, analysis and interpretation of data, and presentation of findings to various types of audiences.
